subject: Re: [junit] Testing abstract classes
msgSnippet: Yes, its normally better to test Abstract classes through their deriving classes.  This way you are testing the real classes that are certain to be used,
messageBody:
Yes, its normally better to test Abstract classes through their deriving
classes. This way you are testing the real classes that are certain to be
used, whereas any method on an abstract base class is viable for over
riding.

If it turns out that you are writing the same tests for each of the derived
classes, because they only implement one or a small number of the abstract
base classes methods, and you feel like its an exercise in typing out
tests.... Then 'the code' is telling you the design is wrong. Wrong, as
in, why use Inheritance if all the derived classes do is add a single extra
implementation detail. The cure for this is to 'Favour Delegation over
Inheritance'.

What would the design look like if you used delegation to call those extra
classes instead of virtual polymorphic calls?

E.g. Inheritance


class Car {
abstract String getMake();
}

class BMW extends Car {
String getMake() {
returns "BMW";
}
}

class Toyota extends Car
String getMake() {
returns "Toyota";
}
}

Q: Do we Test Each class or abstract base class

E.g. Delegation (Note using the String class as the class to delegate to -
but it could easily be one of your own classes)

class Car {
private String make;

Car(String aMake) {
make = aMake;
}

String getMake() {
return make;
}
}


class CarTest {

@Test
testMakeOfCars() {
Car bmw = new Car("BMW");
assertEquals("Wrong make!", "BMW", bmw.getMake() );

Car toyota = new Car("Toyota");
assertEquals("Wrong make!", "Toyota", toyota.getMake() );
}
}
